reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s optimism about moral trade being enabled by superintelligence via “iron-clad contracts.” Trade/compromise is a major pillar of the essay’s conditional optimism (esp. section 3), but not the only route discussed, and the essay hedges that institutions and realized trade are uncertain; thus centrality is moderate rather than decisive. The objection is substantively strong: for high-stakes inter-agent bargains with copying, self-modification, delegation, and hidden channels, contract enforcement/identity/observability are nontrivial and the essay doesn’t specify enforcement primitives, so the ‘contracts solve trust’ move is under-argued and could fail in precisely the most important cases. Still, it doesn’t fully refute trade (there could be other enforcement mechanisms, norms, or architectures), and the essay only claims superintelligence “could” help. Most claims in the critique are plausible/true at a high level, though it likely overstates by implying section 3’s story collapses entirely and that contracts are the “main enabling technology.” It is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little fluff.
title: Superintelligent contracts lack enforceable primitives when agents can fork or self-modify
